author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: California Wildfire Burns More Than 900 Acres and Prompts Evacuations
description: The Rices fire is burning near South Yuba River State Park in Nevada County, Calif., about 70 miles northeast of Sacramento.
content: A fast-growing fire near South Yuba River State Park in Nevada County, Calif., about 70 miles northeast of Sacramento, has grown to more than 900 acres in two days, prompting evacuation orders for hundreds of residents of nearby communities, the authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Here’s your Fourth of July forecast, America.
description: Some parts of the Great Plains could feel like a ‘hot blow dryer.’
content: Hot dogs. Apple pie. Sweat stains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Will There Be Enough Monkeypox Vaccine?
description: A factory making Jynneos, the safest vaccine, has been closed since August, threatening global supplies as the virus spreads.
content: As the United States begins a vaccination campaign against monkeypox, concerns are mounting among some experts that the demand may soon far exceed the available supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Cardi B’s All-Star Team-Up, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Raye, Steve Lacy, Moor Mother and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Our Brilliant $100 Bet
description: It started in a Chinese restaurant and ended in the aisles of Costco.
content: When I first read Mark Jason Williams’s essay in the Modern Love submission inbox, I laughed, sighed and nodded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Why Judges Keep Recusing Themselves From a N.Y.C. Vaccine Mandate Case
description: The city’s teachers, who sued over vaccine requirements, said the judges assigned to the case owned thousands of dollars of Covid-19 vaccine-maker stock, which could affect their rulings.
content: It’s a routine step when someone files a lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan: The case is randomly assigned to a judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trisha Pasricha
title: How Common Is Pancreatitis After a Colonoscopy?
description: The musician Travis Barker was hospitalized on Tuesday after reportedly having a colonoscopy. Here’s what to know.
content: Travis Barker, an American musician and drummer for the rock band Blink-182, was hospitalized on Tuesday with pancreatitis, TMZ first reported. The musician had endured “extreme stomach pain,” according to People magazine, and was later wheeled into Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles on a stretcher and accompanied by his wife, Kourtney Kardashian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Dispute Surprise Medical Bills
description: After receiving a $21,500 doctor’s bill for a mere 10 stitches, I researched bad medical billing. Here’s how to fight it.
content: In October, I received a doctor’s bill for $21,500 for treatment my daughter received in the emergency room of a local hospital after suffering a one-inch cut on her forehead. I remember opening the bill while walking down my driveway and nearly having a heart attack: How could 10 measly stitches possibly cost more than 20 grand? And why were we being billed for services we’d received at a hospital that was in our insurance company’s network?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: TikTok tells Republican senators how it plans to keep American data away from China.
description: “We know we are among the most scrutinized platforms from a security standpoint,” the video app’s chief executive wrote.
content: TikTok gave U.S. lawmakers more details in a letter dated Thursday about how it plans to keep data about its American users separate from ByteDance, its Chinese parent company, aiming to combat concerns that the video app poses a national security risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: After ‘Rocketman’, Taron Egerton Transforms Again for ‘Black Bird’
description: The 32-year-old plays an imprisoned drug dealer facing an unusual choice in the Apple TV+ series, written by Dennis Lehane.
content: Taron Egerton channeled a pop god in the Elton John biopic “Rocketman,” winning raves — and a Golden Globe — for his portrayal of how a shy piano prodigy blossomed into an international superstar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Visiting Venice? Make a Reservation and Be Ready to Pay.
description: City officials are introducing a new fee to visit Venice and its islands, a move, they hope, will limit tourists.
content: ROME — Traveling to Venice? Get ready to pay for the privilege of visiting the city, one of the most beautiful on earth. Oh, and be sure to reserve your spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Growing Closer One (Very) Late Dinner at a Time
description: Alaina Collura and Joseph Durkin got to know each other better over late-night meals, one of which, at the Spotted Pig in August 2016, marked a turning point in their relationship.
content: Alaina Korinne Collura had just transferred to a new department at the public accounting firm Ernst & Young in New York when she was put on a project with Joseph Vincent Durkin, in March 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Eurozone inflation rises to 8.6 percent, the highest ever, driven by energy prices.
description: Nearly half the countries in the currency area have now reached double-digit inflation.
content: Record energy prices drove the inflation rate for the countries using the common European currency to 8.6 percent over the year through June, as the fallout of the war in Ukraine and the economic conflict it has set off between Russia and Western Europe continued to bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 4: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 8 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 19.
content: Welcome to Week Four of our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Supreme Court Is the Final Word on Nothing
description: It, too, can be checked and balanced.
content: The U.S. Constitution contains several idle provisions: words, phrases and clauses that have little to no bearing on our constitutional order as it currently exists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: California Requires Plastics Makers to Foot the Bill for Recycling
description: The landmark legislation also restricts single-use plastics. Because California’s economy is so big, experts say, the law could have far-reaching effects.
content: In one of the most ambitious statewide attempts to reduce dependence on plastics, California instituted a new requirement that makers of packaging pay for recycling and reduce or eliminate single-use plastic packaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Solveig Gold Is Proud to Be the Wife of a ‘Canceled’ Princeton Professor
description: But she also wants to be known as more. At dinner with the aspiring public intellectual and her “cabal.”
content: PRINCETON, N.J. — Solveig Lucia Gold was setting the table in her backyard, next door to the house once occupied by Albert Einstein. Her yard is a sweeping field of emerald green grass leading down to the 18th-century blacksmith’s cottage with stone floors that houses her home study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Circling the Bases as Baseball Nears Its Midpoint
description: As teams close in on 81 games, Justin Verlander is showing the kids how it’s done, Aaron Judge continues to mash and the most valuable player (by WAR) isn’t who you think.
content: The All-Star break has typically been used to split up baseball’s first and second halves. While that has always been misleading — teams often play around 90 games in the first half, leaving only 72 for the second half — it is even more extreme this season as the All-Star Game won’t be held until July 19, the latest it has been played in a full season since 1977.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: Susan Orlean and Brandon Taylor
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: UNTIL JUSTICE BE DONE: America’s First Civil Rights Movement, from the Revolution to Reconstruction, by Kate Masur. (Norton, 496 pp., $20.) In this “cleareyed” and “revelatory” book, as the Times critic Jennifer Szalai called it, Masur traces a struggle for racial equality going back to the early days of the republic and recounts the victories that led to achievements such as the Civil Rights Act of 1866 and the 14th Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia Hints at Linking Griner’s Case to Fate of ‘Merchant of Death’
description: Viktor Bout, a Russian arms dealer, is serving a 25-year prison sentence in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — She is an American professional basketball star, accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Novel About Brilliant Young Game Designers
description: Gabrielle Zevin talks about “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow,” and Morgan Talty discusses “Night of the Living Rez.”
content: Gabrielle Zevin’s new novel, “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow,” is set in the world of video game design, and follows two friends named Sadie and Sam as they collaborate on what becomes a very successful game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: From a Chef’s Burnout, a Singular Los Angeles Restaurant Emerges
description: At Angry Egret Dinette, Wes Avila is making ambitious food with freewheeling charm and unfussy service.
content: Wes Avila made his name popping up around Los Angeles selling wildly expressive tacos, his improbable mission in the name: Guerrilla Tacos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Germany Begins Return of Benin Bronzes to Nigeria
description: Two of the renowned artifacts were given back to Nigeria on Friday, and Germany intends to give the African country ownership of some 1,100 more.
content: Germany returned two of the priceless artifacts known as the Benin Bronzes to Nigeria on Friday, after reaching a political agreement that could soon see hundreds more return to the country from which they were looted over 100 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Where Does the Climate Movement Go Next?
description: Al Gore weighs in on the Supreme Court’s recent ruling against the Environmental Protection Agency and explains why climate change is a “crisis of American democracy.”
content: The year was 1989. Al Gore was writing about countries that now no longer exist and world leaders who are no longer alive. But his message was the same: “Earth’s fate is the No. 1 national security issue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: As Federal Climate-Fighting Tools Are Taken Away, Cities and States Step Up
description: Across the country, local governments are accelerating their efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions, in some cases bridging partisan divides. Their role will become increasingly important.
content: Legislators in Colorado, historically a major coal state, have passed more than 50 climate-related laws since 2019. The liquor store in the farming town of Morris, Minn., cools its beer with solar power. Voters in Athens, Ohio, imposed a carbon fee on themselves. Citizens in Fairfax County, Va., teamed up for a year and a half to produce a 214-page climate action plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s New Prime Minister, Yair Lapid, Played the Long Game to Power
description: Once mocked for his inexperience and perceived arrogance, Israel’s caretaker premier taught voters a lesson in political maturity and humility.
content: JERUSALEM — Nearly a decade ago Yair Lapid, then the new leader of Israel’s political center, was asked by a television interviewer if he envisaged becoming prime minister after the next election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sesani
title: What’s happening in the states? Here’s the latest on which abortion laws are in effect and which are blocked.
description: Seven states have now outlawed abortion, but federal judges in Kentucky, Louisiana and Utah have temporarily blocked “trigger bans” in those states from taking effect.
content: A tug of war over the future of abortion access is playing out in courts across the United States after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, adding to a legal landscape defined by uncertainty, confusion and rapid change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano
title: A Transformative Term at the Most Conservative Supreme Court in Nearly a Century
description: The blockbuster decisions — on abortion, guns, religion and climate — told part of the story. But the court’s abrupt rightward shift ran through its entire docket.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court moved relentlessly to the right in its first full term with a six-justice conservative majority, issuing far-reaching decisions that will transform American life. It eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, recognized a Second Amendment right to carry guns outside the home, made it harder to address climate change and expanded the role of religion in public life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an unconventional French rom-com, a triptych about Indigenous women in Mexico, a provincial Tamil satire and more.
content: Cédric Klapisch’s unconventional meet-cute drama dwells entirely in what happens before rather than after the fateful meeting of two would-be lovers. The film opens with a shot of a man and woman seated next to each other on a train in Paris. We soon realize that these are our protagonists — Rémy (François Civil), a factory worker, and Mélanie (Ana Girardot), a lab researcher — but that they’re strangers to one another. They live in adjacent buildings, frequent the same supermarket and visit the same pharmacy to seek medication for opposing ailments: Rémy can’t sleep; Mélanie sleeps too much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender, Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Eyes Early 2024 Announcement as Jan. 6 Scrutiny Intensifies
description: Donald Trump has accelerated his campaign planning, hoping a White House bid will blunt a series of damaging revelations. Some Republicans are worried.
content: Republicans are bracing for Donald J. Trump to announce an unusually early bid for the White House, a move designed in part to shield the former president from a stream of damaging revelations emerging from investigations into his attempts to cling to power after losing the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: With Climate Agenda Stalled at Home, Biden Still Hopes to Lead Abroad
description: The United States has demonstrated international leadership on climate change in the past, but recent setbacks are presenting new challenges for President Biden.
content: On his first day in office, President Biden recommitted the United States to the Paris climate agreement, noting in his inaugural address that “a cry for survival comes from the planet itself. A cry that can’t be any more desperate or any more clear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A major climate-related court ruling.
content: The U.S. Supreme Court limited the Environmental Protection Agency’s powers to restrict carbon emissions from power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Real ‘Only Murders’ Building, and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Vivian Wang
title: Xi Tells a Muted Hong Kong That Political Power Is for Patriots
description: The Chinese leader’s first visit to the former British colony since a sweeping crackdown was a declaration of victory, an assertion of power and a warning to critics.
content: HONG KONG — Under swarms of security, beneath clouds threatening rain, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, marked the 25th anniversary of Hong Kong’s return to China with a showcase of just how thoroughly he had transformed and subdued this once-freewheeling city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Jason Williams
title: A Bet She Couldn’t Resist
description: For $100, could I stop flirting with men when my mother was around? And could she stop talking about my brush with mortality?
content: “Why aren’t you eating?” my mother said to me, her Yonkers accent blaring into the otherwise hushed Chinese restaurant. A 77-year-old Italian-American hairdresser who believed that almost all problems could be solved with a pile of spaghetti and meatballs, she viewed my lack of appetite as a warning flare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media is subpoenaed in federal inquiry of Truth Social deal.
description: The investigation threatens to delay a merger that would provide Trump Media and its platform, Truth Social, with up to $1.3 billion.
content: The investigation by federal prosecutors and securities regulators into a proposed merger between a cash-rich blank check company and former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company has gotten closer to Mr. Trump’s end of the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google Says It Will Delete Location Data When Users Visit Abortion Clinics
description: Under pressure from employees and supporters of reproductive rights, the company announced privacy changes for the post-Roe era.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that it would delete abortion clinic visits from the location history of its users, in the company’s first effort to address how it will handle sensitive data in the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dexter Palmer
title: Strange Histories: Four New Novels Weave Past and Present
description: Whether through reinvention or homage, these books find endless possibilities in events and figures from other times.
content: Initially, Abbigail Nguyen Rosewood’s CONSTELLATIONS OF EVE (Texas Tech University, 211 pp., $29.95) looks as if it’s going to be a straightforward chronicle of the bad decisions of beautiful people — a romance whose initial meet-cute contains the seeds of its ultimate failure, a female friendship whose intense closeness is linked to its acute toxicity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Tennis Gets Another Fairy Tale, Maybe the Craziest One Yet
description: Tim van Rijthoven is a perfect 8-0 in the last month. Before that, and seven years into his professional career, he had yet to win a main-draw match.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Tennis has had its share of come-out-of-nowhere stories in recent years. A qualifier named Emma Raducanu won the U.S. Open last September. The sport is as deep as it has ever been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: The Greatest Grilled Corn Is Glazed
description: A honey-butter glaze does double duty, infusing your corn and keeping it hot, J. Kenji López-Alt writes.
content: When cooking fresh sweet corn for one, nothing beats the microwave: A single ear, in its husk, goes in at full power for three minutes. The husk traps steam, giving the kernels such an intense corn flavor and juiciness that butter becomes nearly superfluous (nearly). But for a crowd? You have more options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘53% Of’ Review: Zinging Pro-Trump Women, and Everyone Else
description: A new comedy by Steph Del Rosso starts as a satire of conservatives, then takes aim at progressives. Too bad the jokes barely cut either side.
content: In America, to vote in a federal election is to commit a secret act. One votes in private, in a curtained booth, on intimate terms with an oversize ballot. But little in American public life stays private for long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid
title: Pictures of Brittney Griner in custody offer few clues to her well-being.
description: Images of the W.N.B.A. star released since her arrest in an airport near Moscow on Feb. 17 have been scrutinized for clues about her mental and physical health.
content: Photos of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner being led through a courthouse outside Moscow were released this week before her trial on drug charges that is set to begin on Friday, giving the Western world a rare glimpse of her after four months of being detained in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: A Chameleon Flies From ‘The Blacklist’ to ‘The Kite Runner’
description: After nine seasons on the NBC series, Amir Arison is making his Broadway debut in the stage adaptation of Khaled Hosseini’s popular 2003 novel.
content: An early scene in the new Broadway play “The Kite Runner” is mostly spoken in Dari, the Afghan dialect of Farsi, though the action depicts a distinctly American art form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Putin moves to seize a large gas venture in Russia’s Far East.
description: Shell and two Japanese companies, Mitsui and Mitsubishi, are minority shareholders in the Sakhalin-2 joint venture.
content: Russia is moving to take over an important natural gas joint venture, putting the investments of Shell and two Japanese energy trading companies at risk in a seizure of a significant foreign investment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Israel Parliament Collapse Sets Up 5th Election in 4 Years
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 1, 2022.
content: “I have no energy to vote again. I feel I am being forced to vote. I feel I am being held hostage by small and foul-smelling politics.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amil Niazi
title: Beer Runs, Porcupine Hunts, Jars of Teeth and Much More
description: In a brash, irreverent story collection, “Night of the Living Rez,” Morgan Talty illuminates life and death on the Penobscot Indian Nation reservation.
content: If you had to trace a line through your history, connect your past to your present, what shape would it take? In Morgan Talty’s debut collection, “Night of the Living Rez,” it forms something like a circle, one that snakes through the past but always ends up in the present, in the madness and joy of today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘The Mutes’ Gives Voice to Musical Outsiders
description: In Paris, a moving and wistful performance installation by Lina Lapelyte gathers untrained singers for reflections on regret and inability.
content: PARIS — The first time I sang, it was by ear. I imagine that’s often the case. Toddlers join their favorite characters in Disney movies or echo their parents with mumbled renditions of “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.” When children begin to sing in school, they usually learn not from scores, but from lyrics memorized through repetition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Austin Butler Cause Hysteria in ‘Elvis’
description: The director Baz Luhrmann narrates a sequence in which Elvis gives an early performance that stirs up the audience.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Is There Anything Funny About the War in Ukraine?
description: At the Cultural Defense shows in Lviv, comedians and audiences look for humor amid a deadly conflict. Don’t mind the air raid alarms.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Some morsels of news are so grim and absurd that they sound like they were conceived in the warped imagination of bored satirists. Like the headline from Belarus a few weeks ago, reporting that 10th graders there were being taught how to aim rifles — using shovels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Reflects on This Year in the Supreme Court
description: Colbert referred to the court’s year of bold rulings as “a real roller-coaster ride, in that I am nauseous and scared we’re all going to die.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Long Live the Theater’: Mariupol’s Drama Company to Perform Again
description: Thirteen members of the Mariupol Drama Theater have reconvened in western Ukraine where they are rehearsing a new play about a Ukrainian dissident who died in a Russian prison camp in the 1980s.
content: UZHHOROD, Ukraine — Dressed in black, the actors moved around a sparse rehearsal room preparing a new play — the story of a dissident Ukrainian who died in a Russian prison camp decades ago. As they took a break, they gathered in a circle with their arms around each other, laughing and chattering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: ‘Woman’ and ‘Female’ Didn’t Start as Words About Men
description: Culture has shaped perceptions of words.
content: English words referring to or meaning “woman” have interesting histories. In the current political moment, I thought I might share some of them. Each can help us think about ways we may perceive the humanity around us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams and Tania Ganguli
title: Griner’s supporters are imploring the Biden administration to secure her release.
description: The agent of the basketball star Brittney Griner recently coordinated a letter to President Biden urging his administration to strike a deal for her release.
content: Brittney Griner’s family and supporters are increasingly imploring President Biden and the U.S. government to secure her release amid continuing fears that she could be used by Russia in the geopolitical jousting over its war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: From Star Athlete to Political Pawn: Griner Goes on Trial in Russia
description: The American basketball star Brittney Griner has endured months in a Russian prison and the threat of years more, a wartime bargaining chip between Moscow and Washington.
content: Brittney Griner arrived in Russia in February to play basketball, one of the sport’s biggest stars. She arrived in a courtroom outside Moscow on Friday as something else entirely — a potential bargaining chip in Russia’s tense standoff with the West over the war in Ukraine, described by supporters as a hostage of the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Meet the Man Bringing Drama and Joy to Brooklyn’s Nightlife Spaces
description: Through carefully designed D.J. booths, bars and doorways, Safwat Riad has been setting the tone for New York City nightlife venues for more than a decade.
content: Push open the right unassuming black door beneath the elevated subway tracks at the Myrtle Avenue/Broadway stop in Brooklyn and you’ll enter a smoky room filled with hazy lights and neon orbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Are We Still Monogamous? And 6 Other Questions to Ask Your Partner.
description: After two years of tumult, these essential conversations can help couples talk about what’s working, what’s not and where the relationship is headed.
content: The past two-plus years have been universally tumultuous, and couples therapists say they have been dealing with the fallout in their practices every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jedediah Britton-Purdy
title: Democrats Need Patriotism Now More Than Ever
description: Gripped by anger and despair, Democrats may not want to celebrate this country. But they need patriotism in order to save American democracy.
content: Fourth of July fireworks echo eerily in a divided country. In theory, this patriotic holiday marks what holds us together, beyond all our disagreement. In practice it amplifies American division. The year that Independence Day memorializes, 1776, also lends its name to the Trumpist 1776 Project, a riposte to the 1619 Project. The very idea of patriotism risks becoming a partisan marker: In 2019, fully 76 percent of Republicans and only 22 percent of Democrats said they were “extremely proud” to be American, according to Gallup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Gray walls, books and a Lenin monument: A look inside the lockup where Griner has been held.
description: At least one other well-known foreigner has spent time there: Naama Issachar, the Israeli-American arrested in April 2019 when the Russian police said they had found marijuana in her luggage.
content: The detention facility just outside Moscow where Brittney Griner, the American basketball star, has been held is a former orphanage rebuilt a decade ago to house women jailed before trial and, separately, women serving their prison sentences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: End of a Pandemic Tracker Signifies a New Phase in Travel
description: With air travel approaching prepandemic levels, the Travel desk is saying goodbye to a project it started over two years ago.
content: Hours before President Donald J. Trump blocked nonessential travel from Europe on March 11, 2020, in response to the spiraling coronavirus pandemic, The New York Times’s deputy Travel editor, Elisabeth Goodridge, flew to her home in New York from Brussels, where she had been vacationing with her family. “Countries started shutting down,” Ms. Goodridge remembered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Is Baltimore Big Enough for the Two of Them?
description: The internet has pretty much killed local news wars. The Baltimore Banner, a nonprofit start-up, is trying to change that by taking on The Baltimore Sun.
content: BALTIMORE — Local news wars have largely gone the way of the phone booth as newspapers have shriveled and reporter jobs have been cut. But one is taking shape in Baltimore, bringing a new kind of rivalry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manan Luthra
title: ‘Wearing a Piece of History’: Vintage Clothing Stores Find a Growing Market
description: The demand for repurposed clothes is rising in Australia, store owners say, as shoppers look for sustainability and history over fast fashion.
content: Until recently, I had never realized how drab my wardrobe is. I do a bit of acting in my spare time and was booked for a project that required me to source my own outfit. I didn’t think too much about the request — low-budget films often ask actors to wear what they have — but the instruction to find something “bright, colorful and unbranded” was proving difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Robin
title: Richard Taruskin, Vigorously Polemical Musicologist, Dies at 77
description: Author, critic, teacher and public intellectual, he was an unabashed flamethrower who challenged conventional thinking about classical music.
content: Richard Taruskin, a commanding musicologist and public intellectual whose polemical scholarship and criticism upended conventional classical music history, died early Friday in Oakland, Calif. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: This $20 Device Turns a Handgun Into an Automatic Weapon
description: Last year, U.S. officials seized 1,500 guns with “auto sears” — and experts suggest they account for a small fraction of the total that exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Victoria Kim
title: Missile Strikes on Ukraine Kill at Least 21 Near Odesa
description: The strikes hit a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port city of Odesa.
content: At least 21 people were killed and dozens were injured when Russian missiles struck a residential tower and a recreational center in a coastal town southwest of the Black Sea port of Odesa early Friday, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Chip Shortage Puts a Big Dent in U.S. Auto Sales
description: General Motors, Toyota and Honda reported substantial declines in second-quarter sales, but not for lack of demand.
content: The auto industry is facing worrying signs all across its horizon, including rising interest rates and fears of a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: The Giant African Land Snail Has Been Spotted Again in Florida
description: Wash your lettuce.
content: MIAMI — The giant African land snail, which can grow to the size of a fist and carry a parasite that causes meningitis, was declared eradicated from South Florida last year after a decade-long battle of people versus pests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Falling Fast, Then Fiancés for Seven Years
description: Luke Kalat knew he wanted to marry Justin Conner after their first conversation in 2010. More than a decade later, he did.
content: Late on a September evening in 2010, as Luke Neville Kalat was preparing to head home from a dance party at Bowlmor Lanes near Manhattan’s Union Square, he noticed a man staring at him from across the room. That man was Justin Claude Conner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Ending a Decade-Long Decline, More Mexicans Are Migrating to U.S.
description: The death of at least 53 migrants in Texas, more than half of whom were from Mexico, is testing U.S. efforts to enlist Mexico in deterring migration.
content: SAN MARCOS ATESQUILAPAN, Mexico — The teenage brothers were among some 80 young men who had left San Marcos in the last two months, a growing exodus from this impoverished village of 1,600 that sits in the lush mountains of Veracruz state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon get festive in the fields.
content: ACROSTIC — This puzzle solves to a passage from a particularly wonderful book, “Braiding Sweetgrass: Indigenous Wisdom, Scientific Knowledge and the Teachings of Plants.” The author, Robin Wall Kimmerer, is a botanist and a member of the Citizen Potawatomi Nation, and her descriptions of flora and fauna are marvelous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelba Márquez-Greene
title: Stop Asking Those Closest to Tragedy to Do the Heaviest Lifting
description: Ask more of our legislators and less of those grieving.
content: Nearly a decade has passed since my daughter, Ana Grace, was shot and killed along with 19 other children and six staff members at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn. If you’re looking for a family’s “tragedy to triumph” narrative, as I suspect many are, I can’t give that to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Taking the ‘Flation’ Out of Stagflation
description: The trench seems to have recovered its anchor, or something.
content: A funny thing happened on the way to the Federal Reserve’s latest rate hike. The Fed went big on June 15, raising the interest rates it controls by 75 basis points, or 0.75 percentage points — a sharp rise for an institution that usually tries to move gradually. Why the urgency? As Jerome Powell, the Fed chairman, made clear, he and his colleagues were afraid that expectations of inflation were becoming “unanchored,” which some economists argue could lead to inflation becoming “entrenched.” (The trench is losing its anchor? Time to call in the mixed-metaphor police? Never mind.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: The Perils of Slow Vote-Counting and Delayed Election Results
description: Slow vote counts were the bane of the 2020 elections, inviting bogus fraud charges. But they’re not going away anytime soon.
content: What happens when Election Day lasts for weeks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: From the Early Morning Sky, Shards of Hot Metal
description: Ukrainians reacted in fury to a Russian missile strike near Odesa, the latest in a string of attacks on civilian targets.
content: SERHIIVKA, Ukraine — His forehead cut from his rescue efforts in the rubble of a hotel in this sleepy southern resort town, Oleksandr Mararenko carried out the bodies of a woman and child early Friday morning after a Russian missile attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: The Secret to Summer’s Best No-Sweat Dessert
description: There’s nothing to fear about making airy, just-rich-enough chocolate mousse. Genevieve Ko writes that you start by learning to let go.
content: I didn’t fully understand the appeal of chocolate mousse until a decade ago, when I had it at the home of my friends Cecile and Tom Renna. They hosted brunch on a July afternoon so oppressively humid, I couldn’t imagine eating much at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The Fourth of July weekend will test airlines struggling to bounce back.
description: After shedding staff in the pandemic, airlines are scrambling to respond to increased demand.
content: Delays and cancellations have plagued air travel, and the Fourth of July weekend may be the biggest test yet for the airline industry, which has faced scrutiny from customers, regulators and investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How TikTok Became a Best Seller Machine
description: #BookTok, where enthusiastic readers share reading recommendations, has gone from being a novelty to becoming an anchor in the publishing industry and a dominant driver of fiction sales.
content: Many of this year’s best selling books have something in common, but it’s not any of the usual factors: a famous or long-established author, a tie-in with a movie or TV show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Epic Tacos
description: We can’t think of a better recipe for a day off than Pati Jinich’s take on Sonoran carne asada tacos.
content: I had originally planned to talk about burgers with you today — these clever fast and juicy smash burgers from J. Kenji López-Alt in particular. It’s the Fourth of July. I get it. I also like a good hamburger, and that’s a really good hamburger.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 1, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 1, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about Turkey’s decision not to Bar Sweden and Finland from NATO referred incorrectly to Finland. It is a Nordic not a Scandinavian country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G Smith
title: How Delta-8 THC Works — and Why Experts Are Worried About It
description: This popular cannabis product claims to be milder than regular marijuana. But is it legal? And is it safe?
content: Over the past few years, you may have seen headlines about a drug called delta-8. Google searches for the term grew by more than 850 percent in the United States between 2020 and 2021, particularly in states where recreational marijuana is illegal. According to one recent study, 16 percent of regular marijuana users also use delta-8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Bonnie Makes Landfall in Nicaragua
description: Bonnie lashed Nicaragua and Costa Rica late Friday after becoming the second named storm of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
content: Tropical Storm Bonnie became the second named storm of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season on Friday, amping up to nearly 50 miles per hour before making landfall in southeastern Nicaragua late in the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Workers at Airports Have Had It
description: Across Europe, airport and other transport employees are striking, disrupting summer travel plans to demand better staffing and pay.
content: PARIS — For 18 years, Marie Marivel has worked as a security agent at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, screening throngs of passengers and thousands of bags each day. It has always been a taxing job, she says, but conditions have lately made it downright impossible, as staffing shortages nearly double her workload and a cost-of-living crisis plunders her modest paycheck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Tunisia’s President Drafts Constitution Giving Himself Broad Powers
description: The proposal, which will be put to a national referendum on July 25, would enshrine the significant steps he has taken over the past year to dismantle the North African nation’s young democracy.
content: CAIRO — Tunisia’s president has taken another major step toward dismantling the country’s young democracy in a newly released draft constitution, giving himself broad powers while diluting those of Parliament and the judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Through an Old-School Setup, a Matchmaker Meets Her ‘Sinatra’
description: An old-fashioned fix-up, and an appreciation for chivalry, brought Erin Bellsey and Charles Leonard together.
content: Erin Courtney Bellsey has always loved playing matchmaker. By her count, she has paired dozens of couples, two of which are now engaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: A Lentil Soup With Its Heart in Armenia
description: Tsirani vosp apur gets its distinctive earthy, tangy flavor from apricots, the country’s national fruit.
content: For her birthday, my friend Audrey wanted one thing: a lentil soup from Yerevan Market and Cafe, an Armenian spot in the Adams Morgan neighborhood of Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: New Zealand Designates Proud Boys a Terrorist Group
description: The far-right Proud Boys are not known to operate in the country, but the designation makes it illegal for New Zealanders to support them.
content: New Zealand has declared the Proud Boys, the far-right American group that played a key role in the deadly storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, to be a terrorist organization, making it illegal for New Zealanders to participate in or support its activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Gratz
title: Profiles in Courage
description: A new historical fiction series for young readers highlights “the importance of standing up for what you know is right.”
content: I was speaking to a gymnasium full of American middle schoolers once about a book I’d written on the Holocaust when a boy raised his hand and asked, “Was everybody from Nazi evil?” I’d been discussing the Holocaust for 45 minutes and the whole time he’d heard “Nazi Germany” as “Nazi, Germany,” as though I were saying a place name like “Atlanta, Georgia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Jan. 6 Witness Anthony Ornato Is at the Center of a Battle Over Credibility
description: Mr. Ornato, who was Donald Trump’s deputy chief of staff for operations, has become a key figure in a dispute over testimony from the Jan. 6 committee’s star witness.
content: Anthony M. Ornato had left his role as the Secret Service agent in charge of President Donald J. Trump’s protective detail in late 2019 when the culture of internal strife that Mr. Trump fostered throughout his term left the president’s top advisers frantically searching for a candidate to fill a key role: deputy White House chief of staff for operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Vladimir Zelenko, 48, Dies; Promoted an Unfounded Covid Treatment
description: A self-described “simple country doctor,” he won national attention in 2020 when the White House embraced his hydroxychloroquine regimen.
content: Vladimir Zelenko, a self-described “simple country doctor” from upstate New York who rocketed to prominence in the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic when his controversial treatment for the coronavirus gained White House support, died on Thursday in Dallas. He was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Neglected Titanic Memorial: ‘Like Their Graves Have Not Been Tended’
description: A fledgling preservation group is urging the restoration of the long-suffering memorial lighthouse, but funds are scarce.
content: On a landlocked street corner at the entrance to the South Street Seaport stands a shabby, rust-streaked old lighthouse, its lantern dark, dwarfed by modern towers to its south and west. Passed with scarcely a glance by most people heading to the shops and bars on Fulton Street, this is the 109-year-old Titanic Memorial Lighthouse, which once presided over the East River waterfront from a far prouder height, shining its fixed green beacon miles out to Sandy Hook, at the southern entrance of Lower New York Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia hints at linking Griner’s case to Viktor Bout, a Russian known as the ‘Merchant of Death.’
description: WASHINGTON — She is an American professional basketball star, accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage.
content: WASHINGTON — She is an American professional basketball star, accused of carrying hashish oil in her luggage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Will Companies Help Their Employees Get Abortions?
description: There’s no ducking this fight.
content: Like it or not, business owners are being sucked into the fight over abortion. Now that the Supreme Court has ended the federal protection of abortion rights, the battle has moved on to whether companies will help their employees get abortions in any way, including by reimbursing them for expenses to travel out of state to obtain a legal procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Paramedic (and Memoirist) Spends His Sundays
description: Anthony Almojera reports to Station 40 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where he cooks a family meal for his 12-member crew.
content: Anthony Almojera is a paramedic and a lieutenant for the New York City Fire Department, working out of Station 40 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. He is also the author of a new memoir, “Riding the Lightning: A Year in the Life of a New York City Paramedic,” which chronicles his experiences during the worst part of the pandemic in the city, and his recovery from a deep depression, including a suicide attempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Inside the Extreme Effort to Punish Women for Abortion
description: Abortion “abolitionists” are the outer edge of the anti-abortion movement. They’re looking to gain followers after the decision to overturn Roe, unsettling mainstream anti-abortion groups.
content: Hours after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last week, a man with a wiry, squared-off beard and a metal cross around his neck celebrated with his team at a Brazilian steakhouse. He pulled out his phone to livestream to his followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Partying in a Pandemic
description: A look at New York City nightlife.
content: For the past few years, Covid has made it complicated — or outright impossible — to go out on the town in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Films of 2022, So Far
description: Here are the movies that our critics say have made the year a strong one onscreen.
content: A little over halfway through 2022, the year in movies has already been intriguing, with one of the best-reviewed releases so far topping the box office. That would be “Top Gun: Maverick.” But if you’ve already seen it and want to catch up on other strong films, I asked The Times’s co-chief critics, A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, for their favorites. Here they are, in no particular order. — Stephanie Goodman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: In ‘Corps,’ Running Aspirational Dance Drills
description: The choreographer Milka Djordjevich’s work at New York Live Arts investigates regimented movement before opening up to something more joyous and loose.
content: When you hear the words, “Snaps: Go!” you know that Milka Djordjevich’s “Corps” has begun. On Thursday at New York Live Arts, five women descended the stairs through the audience in a single-file line, walking and snapping in time. As they advanced across the stage, a second call — “‘No’-head: Go!” — sounded from the group. To their unison steps and snaps, they added heads turning from side to side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: H.T. Chen, Choreographer of the Asian Experience, Dies at 74
description: He merged Eastern and Western influences in his modern dance works, and his dance center was a cultural anchor in New York’s Chinatown.
content: H.T. Chen, who blended Eastern and Western influences in his choreography, and who with his wife, Dian Dong, established the Chen Dance Center, a cultural hub in New York’s Chinatown for more than 40 years, died on June 12 in Manhattan. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: On Their First Date, Plunging Into a Relationship
description: Stephanie Schulter and Halle Bauer had a first date at the Coney Island Polar Bear plunge in 2018. Three years later, they planned an engagement around the same event.
content: For their first date, Stephanie Schulter and Halle Anne Bauer jumped into the Atlantic together in 17-degree weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: One Dead and 22 Have Been Hospitalized in Listeria Outbreak Tied to Florida
description: A food source has not been identified as the cause of the outbreak, which has sickened people across 10 states starting in January 2021, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a statement.
content: One person has died and 22 people have been hospitalized in a listeria outbreak, with most of the infected people having been in Florida about a month before they became sick, the federal authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Climate Protesters in Australia Face Harsh New Penalties
description: As of April, people in New South Wales who disrupt business activities can face up to two years in prison. Some climate activists say this law is aimed at them.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When climate protesters took to the streets of Sydney this week, including blocking one of its busiest traffic tunnels for over an hour, they faced the fury of government officials who labeled them “professional pests” and warned that they’d see “the book being thrown at them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Court vs. the Climate
description: The Supreme Court seems unconcerned with climate change.
content: The Supreme Court has made it harder for the country to fight the ravages of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: ‘So Stressed Out’: Gas Prices Force Many to Rethink Driving, and Spending
description: As summer trips beckon, some are traveling less, at least by car. And those candy bars at the convenience store may find fewer takers.
content: KATY, Texas — Most Americans would gladly pay the $4.29 for a gallon of regular gas Buc-ee’s was charging this week on Interstate 10 between Houston and San Antonio, more than 50 cents below the national average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: They Uncover New Fossils, but They Also Bite
description: Harvester ants in Nebraska unearthed thousands of fossilized teeth and jaw bones, leading scientists to the discovery of 10 new species.
content: A small group of paleontologists recently discovered 10 species of ancient mammals previously unknown to science. But they had an enormous number of helpers at their dig site: thousands of tiny ants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole V. Bell
title: So You’re Rivals? And You’re Fake-Dating? Classic.
description: In her debut romance novel, “Honey and Spice,” Bolu Babalola plays with familiar literary romance tropes to explore questions about gender, sexuality and modern dating.
content: If she weren’t a writer, Bolu Babalola could be a great cultural anthropologist. Her work is rife with observations that have the richness of field notes. In ethnography, the way she writes would be called thick description — it’s precise, layered and interpretive. In her debut romance novel, “Honey and Spice,” Babalola trains her keen eye and considerable wit on young Black British society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The N.Y.P.D.’s Sex-Crimes Division Faces an Investigation
description: The Special Victims Division is the subject of allegations that its officers shamed and abused survivors of sexual assault.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at a Justice Department civil rights investigation that will examine the Police Department’s Special Victims Division. We’ll also get the latest on upgrading Pennsylvania Station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Will Award Medal of Freedom to Simone Biles, John McCain and Others
description: The medal, the nation’s highest civilian award, will go to barrier-breaking figures as well as prominent political veterans.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced on Friday that he will present the Presidential Medal of Freedom next week to 17 leaders from the worlds of politics, civil rights, sports, business, education and entertainment, including the Olympic gymnast Simone Biles, the actor Denzel Washington and the first American to receive a Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Alex Traub
title: Nine People Are Injured in Newark Shooting, Officials Say
description: The victims — eight adults and one youth — were all in stable condition at Newark hospitals, the acting public safety director said.
content: NEWARK — Nine people were hospitalized after being shot Thursday evening in Newark, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Director of the Chinati Foundation in Marfa to Step Down
description: Jenny Moore is leaving the contemporary art museum established by Donald Judd, after nine years as the director and following the completion of the first part of its multiyear master plan.
content: Jenny Moore and the board of trustees of the Chinati Foundation announced on Friday that Moore will step down on July 31, after nine years as the director of the contemporary art museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Suggests ‘Alien Things’ From the South Brought Covid
description: Airborne propaganda leaflets sent by activists across the border have long angered the regime, which pointed to them as the likely culprit in the country’s recent outbreak.
content: SEOUL — North Korea suggested on Friday that the coronavirus had entered the country on foreign objects from South Korea, saying that its first reported outbreak had begun in villages near the countries’ border after people there touched “alien things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Corey Kilgannon
title: Swimmer at Long Island Beach May Have Been Bitten by Shark, Police Say
description: A laceration on a 57-year-old man’s right foot could have been the result of a shark bite — a rare occurrence in New York’s waters.
content: A man swimming at Jones Beach on Long Island on Thursday may have been bitten by a shark, according to the Nassau County Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Women’s Euros Offer a Summer Free-for-All
description: England will be expecting to win its first major women’s title on home soil this summer. But the field is deep, and filled with contenders.
content: That old, familiar feeling crackled and fizzed into the warm night air as 20,000 fans streamed out of Elland Road last Friday. England had just dismantled the reigning European champion. A major tournament, on home turf, was only a few days away. The weeks ahead seemed to glisten with promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Princess’ Review: Holding His Heart in Her Hands
description: Joey King is credible and compelling as a vengeful would-be princess bride in this over-the-top action fantasy tale.
content: Le-Van Kiet’s fantasy “The Princess” opens in a traditional manner, with the trill of Celtic-inspired flutes, a pink sunrise and a slow climb to the top of a spindly tower, where an unnamed princess-bride-to-be (Joey King) lies on a bed strewn with rose petals. But here, the royal beauty feigns sleep. Five minutes into this slender yet vigorous blood-spattered fable, two enemy guards enter to drag our heroine to the chapel — and she brutally kills them. Clearly, the classic genre that galvanizes Kiet and the screenwriters Ben Lustig and Jake Thornton doesn’t hark back to ye olde European fairy tales but rather to the feminist revenge thrillers of the 1970s: works of exploitation and wuxia cinema where warrior women stuck it to the man. With knives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Pandemic-battered movie theaters are feeling good after a strong June.
description: Films like “Top Gun: Maverick” and “Jurassic World Dominion” performed very well at the box office, and “Minions: The Rise of Gru” is expected to continue the trend.
content: For two years, the film industry lived in genuine fear about the future of moviegoing, with no one able to say for sure whether cinemas would recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Sitting in the dark in a theater to watch moving images — a 117-year-old American pastime that was already in long, slow decline — may well have encountered its extinction-of-the-dinosaurs moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Mark Zuckerberg Prepares Meta Employees for a Tougher 2022
description: In an internal meeting this week, Mr. Zuckerberg said the tech giant was facing one of the “worst downturns that we’ve seen in recent history.”
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg has a message for Meta employees: Buckle up for tough times ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Columbia Won’t Participate in the Next U.S. News Rankings
description: The university, which had climbed to No. 2 in the influential rankings, said it needed more time to address questions about its data, which were raised by a Columbia math professor.
content: Columbia University will not participate in the next U.S. News & World Report rankings of colleges across the country, after a Columbia math professor questioned the accuracy of the data that secured its No. 2 spot in the influential rankings, the university announced on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Corruption in Ukraine
description: We talk to former U.S. ambassador Marie Yovanovitch about the challenges ahead.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Jasmina Nielsen
title: Denmark’s Leader Apologizes for Botched Mink Cull During Pandemic
description: The comments by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen came after a report called the government’s decision in 2020 to kill some 17 million mink over coronavirus fears illegal.
content: When Denmark ordered the culling of its entire population of mink in late 2020 over fears that a mutated version of the coronavirus that had infected mink could diminish the effectiveness of vaccines, millions of animals were killed and farmers were left reeling by a financial burden that Danish taxpayers ultimately will shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: ‘Mango Man’ Is the Fruit’s Foremost Poet, Philosopher, Fan and Scientist
description: With 300 types of mangos to his horticultural credit, Kaleem Ullah Khan is quick to tell anyone in India and beyond about the infinite potential of the fruit and its tree, including as medicine.
content: MALIHABAD, India — Theirs is a friendship of over half a century, the old man and his mango tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: While Following Grateful Dead Tribute Bands, a Romantic Turn
description: Caroline Cornell and Daniel Logan have been friends since middle school in Vermont, but their relationship didn’t become romantic until many years later when the two were living transiently.
content: Caroline Cornell and Daniel Patrick Logan weren’t technically off the grid when they found romance on the Lost Coast of Northern California, the state’s most remote oceanfront area, in the summer of 2014. But the routes each had taken to get there could definitely be described as off the beaten path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: A Blow to Regulators
description: Plus, what to do about the airlines’ cancelation-athon ahead of a busy holiday travel weekend.
content: The Supreme Court yesterday limited the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to regulate power plant emissions, dealing a significant blow to the Biden administration’s climate change agenda. The ruling is the product of a longstanding campaign by some conservatives to curtail or dismantle the power of the so-called administrative state, the system of agencies that regulate wide areas of the economy. It is already altering the balance of power between businesses and the regulators that oversee them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: A Thriller Plugged Into the Overheated Global Power Grid
description: Daniel Nieh’s “Take No Names,” filled with international intrigue and cross-border conflicts, is a noir novel for the modern age.
content: It’s challenging to write a noir novel set in the modern world. After all, a reliable aspect of classic noir is that the shiny veneer of a placid community is ripped away, revealing teeming rot and societal corruption underneath. (Think of James Ellroy’s “L.A. Confidential” or David Lynch’s film “Blue Velvet.”) How, then, do you set a noir in a current global moment when it feels like rot and corruption are festering all too often in plain sight for everyone to see?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Style Sneakers?
description: A reader wonders if they can ditch their dressy flats for good.
content: Given that Serena Williams wore sneakers with her Versace gown at the Met Gala a few years ago, and since then we’ve had two years of social isolation and comfort dressing, it’s fair to say that at this point sneakers with everything, everywhere is a thing — for pretty much everybody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
description: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced its plan for oil and gas drilling off the coasts of the United States, closing off the possibility of new leases in the Atlantic, Pacific and Arctic Oceans but potentially allowing new lease sales in both the Gulf of Mexico and in Cook Inlet in Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Supreme Court’s E.P.A. Decision Is More Gloom Than Doom
description: The most profound effect of West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency may ultimately be cultural.
content: Many of the headlines about the Supreme Court’s 6-3 ruling on West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday have suggested an existential setback: a major blow to American decarbonization and global climate ambition. But the effect is less like a nail in the coffin and more like putting an additional set of brakes on an already stalled project.
